body:
Welcome to Lesson 4!

In this lesson we are going to refine our opportunity data from Lessons 1 and 2 to refer to those activities and places that are now in our lists, linking it all together.
title: Lesson 4: Using lists with opportunities
instruction: Click the right arrow at the bottom to get started

body:
The table below shows all the properties that can be added to an Event and example values for those you can add now. Some of the properties we will revisit after we have learnt how to use them in the other lessons (e.g. all those which have values of (Object)).

To complete this lesson add a "url" to your event, use the table to help you get the format.

Key Example or exact value
@contexthttps://www.openactive.io/ns/oa.jsonld
typeEvent
urlhttp(s)://....
nameany string
descriptionany string
imagehttp(s)://...
startDateYYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ or YYYY-MM-DD
endDateYYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ or YYYY-MM-DD
durationISO 8601 duration standard
locationany string or (Place object)
Organiser(Object)
Contributor(Object)
Leader(Object)
maximumAttendeeCapacityany number
remainingAttendeeCapacityany number
eventStatushttp://schema.org/EventCancelled
http://schema.org/EventPostponed
http://schema.org/EventRescheduled
http://schema.org/EventScheduled
schedule(Object)
activityany string or (Object)
categoryany string or (Object)
ageRangee.g. "15-20" or "20-60"
genderRestrictionmale
female
mixed
programmeany string or (Object)
attendeeInstructionsany string
displayTitle: 1.6 - The complete set of available attributes for Events
title: 1.6 - The complete set of available attributes for Events

body:
Welcome to Lesson 3!

So far we have just created opportunity data. 

In this lesson we are going to look at how you can describe lists of activities and places which can be referred to within those opportunities.
displayTitle: Lesson 3: Working with lists of activities and places
title: Lesson 3: Working with lists of activities and places
instruction: Click the right arrow at the bottom to get started

body:
Welcome to Lesson 2!

In this lesson we will look at adding more advanced and nested data to our object.

You will discover how JSON is not just about tabular data and how we can nest complex data within a single opportunity data example.

By the end of this lesson you will have:

  • Described an opportunity that consists of multiple activities
  • Added a regular schedule for an opportunity (e.g. weekly)
  • Added a Place to an event
displayTitle: Lesson 2: Adding more detail and nested data
title: Lesson 2: Adding more detail and nested data
instruction: Click the right arrow at the bottom to get started

title: Component title
_defaultValue:
{
  "@context": "https://www.openactive.io/ns/oa.jsonld",
  "type": "Event",
  "url": "http://www.example.org/events/1",
  "name": "Tai chi Class",
  "description": "A tai chi class intended for beginners",
  "startDate": "2017-03-22T20:00:00-05:00",
  "duration": "PT60M",
  "activity": {
    "id": "http://example.org/activity-list#tai-chi",
    "type": "Concept",
    "prefLabel": "Tai chi",
    "altLabel": "Tai-chi",
    "inScheme": "http://example.org/activity-list"
  }
}

title: 1.3 - Adding a start and end date/time

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Make sure your date formats are correct.

By the end of the lesson the student will have been guided through the process of creating data like that on the right. This will also include a place if that is possible?

Exact steps have yet to be decided.
title: Lesson objective

body:
By the end of the lesson the student will have been guided through the process of creating data like that on the right. 

Exact steps have yet to be decided.
title: Lesson objective

body:
This lesson will introduce the basics of the open opportunity data modelling specification. It will guide you through creating a simple piece of opportunity data to describe an event.

Opportunity data is described in the JavaScript Object Notation format. This is a key:value pair format that is a "native" data format on the web. 

Don't worry if you have never created or used this data format before as this module will ensure you can get a good grip on the basics. 

Find out more

The full Modelling Opportunity Data specification is available from the World Wide Web consortium (W3C). The W3C is an international community of people who develop and maintain the web standards. Alongside the specification there is also a primer, designed to show how the specification can be implemented. This tutorial is an interactive version of the primer.
title: Lesson 1: Defining an opportunity
instruction: Click the right arrow at the bottom of the screen to continue.

title: 1.2 - Adding more properties to your object

_incorrect.final: Not quiet! Make sure you have two values (name and description) and you have separated them by a comma ",". They putting name on one line and description on the other. You don't need a comma after your last property!

title: Component title
_defaultValue:
{
 "@context": "https://www.openactive.io/ns/oa.jsonld",
 "type": "Event",
 "name": "General fitness class",
 "url": "http://www.example.org/events/2",
 "duration": "PT60M",
 "activity": ["Aerobics", "Weight Lifting", "Yoga"],
 "category": ["Beginner", "Low intensity"],
 "eventSchedule": {
    "type": "Schedule",
    "startDate": "2017-01-01",
    "endDate": "2017-12-31",
    "frequency": "weekly",
    "byDay": "http://schema.org/Wednesday",
    "startTime": "19:00",
    "endTime": "20:00"
  },
 "location": {
    "type": "Place",
    "name": "ExampleCo Gym",
    "address": {
        "type": "PostalAddress",
        "streetAddress": "1 High Street",
        "addressLocality": "Bristol",
        "postalCode": "BS1 4SD"
    },
    "geo": {
        "latitude": "51.380837",
        "longitude": "-2.3462374"
    }
 }
}

title: Ideal answer
_defaultValue:
{
    "@context": "https://www.openactive.io/ns/oa.jsonld",
    "type": "Event",
    "name": "Tai chi Class",
    "description": "A Tai Chi class intended for beginners",
    "url": "http://www.example.org/events/1",
    "startDate": "2017-03-22",
    "endDate": "2017-03-22",
    "duration": "PT60M",
    "activity": "Tai Chi"
}

body:
By the end of the lesson the student will have been guided through the process of creating data like that on the right. 

Exact steps have yet to be decided.
title: Lesson objective

body:
Which of the following date formats is valid in the opportunity data modelling specification?

A) 2018-12-26

B) 2018-26-12

C) 2018-12-26T10:00:00Z

D) 2018/12/26

E) 26/12/2018
title: Q1: Date formats
instruction: Select up to two answers and then click 'submit'.

body:
You can add more properties to your object, try adding a description:

"description": "A Tai Chi class intended for beginners"

In order to add a new property you MUST put a comma after the previous property.

You need a comma after every property except the last property. E.g. if you have a closing bracket next } or ], then you should not have a comma.

Click 'submit' to validate your answer.

Have you discovered?

The value of each property can be customised; you don't need the description to match the one above. Why not make your description more entertaining and even change the name of your event?
displayTitle: 1.2 - Adding more properties to your object
title: 1.2 - Adding more properties to your object

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Make sure you have included both @context and type properties and set these to the correct values.

body:
To start this lesson we have predefined a fitness class that consists of three "activities". 

Try first to validate this event and see what happens. 

You should notice that this event is invalid. This is because you cannot have an "activities" attribute; it must be activity. 

In order to describe an event with multiple activities we must use the activity attribute and then create an array of activities, each as an individual property. 

In JSON an array is shown by the [ ] brackets and you can have comma separated values in the array.

Try changing the list of activities into an array so it looks like the following: 

"activity": [ "Aerobics", "Weight Lifting", "Yoga" ]

Click submit to check your answer.

Find out more

As as activity can be a string the following is valid in the full specification:

"activity": "Aerobics, Weight Lifting, Yoga"

However to a machine this is one activity with commas in it. The commas could be part of one activity e.g. "Jousting, on horses". It is only by using arrays that a machine can tell that each activity is distinct.
title: 2.1 - Adding a list of activities

body:
Congratulations on completing lesson 1!

You should now be familiar with creating a basic piece of opportunity data that conforms to the opportunity modelling specification.

Section 4.1 of this specification outlines the full data model (shown below).

So far we have created an event that can have 14 properties including name, description and image.

As can be seen in the data model below an Event can also be linked to 5 other data objects representing Places, People, Organisations, Activities and Programmes. 

In the next lesson we are going to discover how to these types of objects and nested data to our events including:

  • Describing an opportunity that consists of multiple activities
  • Adding a regular schedule for an opportunity (e.g. weekly)
  • Adding a Place to an event

 

Next lesson
title: Lesson 1 complete

body:
Finally we must add a few more properties to our data so that people know what type of data you are sharing and which schema it conforms to. 

So far in this lesson we have set the schema for you on pressing the submit button. From now on you should tell users (machines and humans) what type of data you are giving them. This is done by adding a special @context attribution to your data.

"@context": "https://www.openactive.io/ns/oa.jsonld"

This informs the user which data standard the data here conforms to. However this standard defines lots of types of object (more on them later) and we are currently working with the "Event" type:

"type": "Event"

Add both these properties to your data. It is recommended to add them to the top of your data they are a bit like a title and subtitle and help the reader (human or machine) know what to expect.

That is it for describing a basic event.

 

Click 'submit' to check you have got it right and then move to the next step where we will show you the complete list of properties an event can have.
title: 1.5 - Completing the essentials!

body:
JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation. It is used to represent objects like people, places, events etc.

The {} brackets are used to indicate the start and end of an object.

You then define the properties of your object inside the brackets.

Try adding the name of an event to the empty object on the right:

Add the following (including quote marks) between the {} brackets on the right:

"name": "Tai Chi Class"

 

Click "Submit" to check your answer.

Find out more

Upon clicking submit a code validator with both ensure your JSON is correctly structured and that it conforms to the required specification. Any errors will be shown in the box at the bottom. The Open Active opportunity data validator is also available as a stand alone tool here.
title: 1.1 - Defining a JSON object

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Make sure you add a URL to your object.

body:
On the right is an example of the less objective endpoint.

This is what the users should have created for themselves by the end of the lesson having learnt about:

  1. Basic properties (Title, description, activity and url)
  2. Schedule objects (startDate, endData and duration)
  3. Adding the type to define what type of object we are create and the namespace that we need to refer to always.
title: Lesson objective

body:
Even though your event might have a start and end date the actually duration of the activity might be different. 

For example a one hour swim class might be 40 minutes with time allowed for showering and changing after.

You can add a duration property to your event using the ISO 8601 standard for describing a duration. 

Here are a few example durations to help you add yours:

30 minutes = "PT30M"

2 hours = "PT2H"

2 hours 30 minutes = PT2H20M"

 

Add a duration to your event and click 'submit' to check your answer.
title: 1.4 - Adding an activity duration

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Make sure your duration conforms to the specification.

body:
Now we need to add a start and end date to our event. 

This can be in one of a few date formats: 

Try adding startDate and endDate properties with dates in one of the following formats:

  • 2017-12-25
  • 2017-12-25T09:30:00Z

Click 'submit' to check your answer.

Remember you will still need to get all your brackets, quote marks, colons and commas in the right place!

Find out more

This date format is a standard in and of itself known as ISO 8601. It is international standard issued by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 1988. Read more on wikipedia.
displayTitle: 1.3 - Adding a start and end date/time
title: 1.3 - Adding a start and end date/time

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Make sure you have you name between two {} brackets and that you have included quote marks.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Make sure you have you name between two {} brackets and that you have included quote marks.

body:
Our fitness class is "Low intensity" and "Beginner" in level. 

Try adding an array of containing these (or other) categories to the data. 

Remember: You cannot have plurals in the attributes so you will need to use the category attribute.
title: 2.2 - Adding categories
2.1 - Adding a list of activities
_defaultValue:
{
 "@context": "https://www.openactive.io/ns/oa.jsonld",
 "type": "Event",
 "name": "General fitness class",
 "description": "A fitness class of many activities!",
 "url": "http://www.example.org/events/2",
 "duration": "PT60M",
 "activities": "Aerobics, Weight Lifting, Yoga",
 "startDate": "2017-01-01",
 "endDate": "2017-12-31"
}

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

You successfully added an array of activities to your event.

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Be careful to ensure your array starts with a [ bracket and each value is in quote marks and separated by a comma as shown in the example.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

You successfully added an array of categories to your event.

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Note that in this example categories can only be defined as an array, not as a string. You can define them as strings in the full schema.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

You successfully added an array of categories to your event.

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Note that in this example categories can only be defined as an array, not as a string. You can define them as strings in the full schema.

body:
You might have noticed that the predefined fitness class has a duration of 60 minutes, starting on the 1st of January and ending on the 31st of December. But when is the class, what time and is it daily?

In order to define all these properties we can add an eventSchedule attribute to our object. 

To complete this lesson create an eventSchedule attribute and move the startDate and endDate attributes inside this object as follows:

"eventSchedule": {
       "type": "Schedule",
       "startDate": "2017-01-01",
       "endDate": "2017-12-31"
}

Press 'submit' to check your answer.

Did you notice?

An eventSchedule is not a string, nor an array, it is a nested JSON object contained in { } brackets. Just like the way an event is an object with properties, so is an eventSchedule.
title: 2.3 - Event schedules
2.4 - Adding more properties to your eventSchedule

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

Your eventSchedule is getting more detailed, well done!

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

You need to add three properties: frequency, startTime and endTime with values "weekly", "19:00" and "20:00" respectively.

body:
We should now have a basic eventSchedule object, however there are still many pieces of information missing, such as the startTime and endTime of the event and which day of the week it runs on.

Just like the event object itself, the eventSchedule object has a series of properties that you can define according to the data model. The extract of the data model which relates an event to and eventSchedule is shown below.

Try adding a "weekly" frequency to your event, along with a startTime (e.g. "19:00") and endTime. 

We will add byDay in the next step.
displayTitle: 2.4 - Adding more properties to your eventSchedule
title: 2.4 - Adding more properties to your eventSchedule

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

You now have a complete event schedule!

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

Have you included all the required attributes in your eventSchedule ("type", "startDate", "endDate", "frequency", "startTime", "endTime", "byDay")?

Is your byDay value a URL e.g. http://schema.org/Wednesday?

title: 2.6 - Adding a location to your event

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

Nice work, this was a challenging one!

_incorrect.final:
Not quiet!

This is a difficult one. You need to add a location object with the properties, type, name, address and geo. The address and geo objects should have all the properties (except region) shown in the data model diagram. The errors above might not all be helpful, this is due to the complexity of addresses.

body:
The table below shows the detail of what properties and values are valid in an eventSchedule object.

Use this table to expand your eventSchedule, to complete this step you need to add the byDay property.

Key Example or exact value
typeSchedule
startDateISO 8601 date (e.g. 2019-01-04 or 2018-12-18T19:00:00Z)
endDatesee startDate
frequency"hourly", "daily", "weekly", "monthly" or "yearly"
byDayhttp://schema.org/{day} (e.g. http://schema.org/Wednesday)
byMonthDay1-31
byMonth1-12
startTimee.g. 10:30
endTimesee startTime
countNumber in schedule (e.g. 1)
exceptDateSingle ISO 8601 date or array of dates
title: 2.5 - Completing your event

body:
Much like an eventSchedule a location of an event has its own set of properties represented in the location object. Additionally, the location object has subObjects of address and geo (as well as itself) to give fine grain detail to the location of an event.

Can you add the following location to your event?

ExampleCo Gym
1 High Street
Bristol
BS1 4SD
51.380837,-2.3462374

Important note: The location object much have a type of “Place” and the address object a type “PostalAddress“

Use the data model diagram below to help you. Remember that each object should be in its own set of { } brackets, just like eventSchedule.
displayTitle: 2.6 - Adding a location to your event
title: 2.6 - Adding a location to your event

body:
Congratulations, you have now created a fairly complicated event object in JSON that conforms to the opportunity data modelling specification.

You have also mastered the JSON format using arrays and objects!

Before moving on to the next lesson, test your knowledge without our quick quiz on everything you have learnt so far!
title: Well done!
instruction: Click the next arrow to take the quiz

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The opportunity data modelling specification uses the international ISO 8601 date format which allows date formats of either YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM-DDTHH:ii:ssZ. 

Did you know? The reason that this date format is so widely used is that it is the only one that can be sorted alphabetically and maintain perfect order. As a counter example 29/12/2017 and 13/01/2018 sorted alphabetically would put the date in 2018 first as 13 is less than 29.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The opportunity data modelling specification uses the international ISO 8601 date format which allows date formats of either YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM-DDTHH:ii:ssZ. 

Did you know? The reason that this date format is so widely used is that it is the only one that can be sorted alphabetically and maintain perfect order. As a counter example 29/12/2017 and 13/01/2018 sorted alphabetically would put the date in 2018 first as 13 is less than 29.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Although it might seem logical to have a comma separated list, this still causes issues if the value itself has a comma within it. So an array of values should be used. You cannot use object brackets here as values in an object must be key:value pairs whereas in an array they can be many types.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Although it might seem logical to have a comma separated list, this still causes issues if the value itself has a comma within it. So an array of values should be used. You cannot use object brackets here as values in an object must be key:value pairs whereas in an array they can be many types.

body:
So far we have only created one event, which technique would you use to list multiple-events?

A)    Use an array of event objects 

B)    Supply a different JSON document for each event 

C)    Add multiple activities to a single event object
title: Q3: Multiple events
instruction: Select you answer and click submit

body:
Which of the following is the valid way to add a list of activities to an event?

A)    Using a comma separated list in quotes? 

          “activity”: “swimming, cycling, running”

B)    Using a set of objects?

          “activity”: {
                “swimming”,
                “cycling”,
                “running”
          }

C)    Using an array of values?

          “activity”: [
                 “swimming”,
                 ”cycling”,
                 ”running”
          ]
title: Q2: How to list activities?
instruction: Select you answer and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Following on from the last question, an array can contain many different types of data. As well as a simple set of strings (e.g. activities) an array can also contain a set of objects, e.g. events.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Following on from the last question, an array can contain many different types of data. As well as a simple set of strings (e.g. activities) an array can also contain a set of objects, e.g. events.

body:
Well done on completing lesson 2. You should now be able to implement the full data model for opportunity data including all the different sub types such as location.

You might have noticed that so far we have had to put all of the data about all sub types within each event. This causes a lot of data replication. For example is the location properties are always the same then we should be able to manage these separately. This process is often referred to as database normalisation, where data is looked up by reference. 

In the next two lessons we look at how to do this in JSON with web links are start to create an API for our reference data (such as activities, locations and organisers).
title: Lesson 2 complete
